events.text:
I understood the scene in front of me.
After Apple lost, a group of representatives from the Carrot Group escorted her out of the main hall.
I could see tears forming in her eyes as she glanced towards me and Cory while walking off the battleground.
There was no time to exchange words. 
No time to embrace.
Despite arriving together, we had been separated.
I had to do the final part by myself.

I'm sorry, [yourname].
This won't come as a shock to you; in fact I know you knew from the start,
but the final battle will be with me.
Come.

The strange hallway appeared as if we were entering a different world alltogether.
There was solid ground beneath my feet, but it felt as if I was floating in a night's sky. 
I wasn't sure if it was just an optical illusion; a mirror contraption of some kind,
or if we really had entered a new realm.
"Where are we?" I asked as we were stepping through the hallway.
"In the same place we've been before." Cory answered, no doubt sensing the confusion in my voice.
"This is just another part of the tower."
...

I didn't feel exhausted, despite walking for many hours. 
Cory had assured me our destination was close, but somehow I wished I could keep walking with him through this serene environment.
This place felt like a safe blanket. [pause=0.5][br]I missed Apple, but there was never a chance for both of us to be here.
At the end, I couldn't hear her words but I still understood them. [br]That's what was important.
...
..
.
I didn't have many friends growing up.
My parents were big shots in the automobile industry, or so I had been told. [pause=0.5][br]I was never really able to understand what exactly they were doing when I was young.
Later I realized that the definition for "automobile industry" was seriously stretched in their case.
I met Apple at one of the factories my parents owned.
Standing between metal parts I knew immediately that we were going to be friends.
When you grow up as the son of a weapon's manufacturer mogul, you don't really get to enjoy the same benefits as other children your age. 
Unlike many other manufacturers, my father refused to supply what he considered the "enemy" with the same weapons as the countries he considered "us".
And thus, he was the target of the "enemy" faction. 
And thus, we were the target of the "enemy" faction.
As the war went on, I had to be homeschooled in a safe environment. There weren't many children in the same situation as me, my father made sure to not employ anyone with children.
But there was one. 
Apple was my friend. She studied with me, she played with me, she watched anime with me. 
We were inseparable, so much so my father arranged for her family to live in the same location I hid out in.
And so we spent our life together. 
And so we spent our end together.
When we became adults, we decided to become soldiers. 
Our parents were moved to tears. In their eyes, we were walking a blessed path for our country.
We didn't know anything else.
During training, I met the first boys my age. Having gown up mostly around my mother and Apple for the formative years of my life, I quickly realized I wouldn't fit in.
Even when deploying to the battlefield, I still felt out of place among the male members of our squadron. 
But at least Apple had been there. We had each other.
...
..
.

A large tree towered before us. 
I chuckled to myself.
"A tree inside a building that looks like a sapling. That's pretty good."

This is the final room. 
I'm sorry, [yourname]. 
It's not your fault. 
You weren't meant to be here. No one is meant to be here.
But you are. 
The naivety of adolescence filled these halls.
A building meant to mark the beauty of a moment that can only exist for a short time.
You're the last visitor.
...
He looked at me with eyes that contained the fear of everyone that walked these corridors.
